channel.title: Some new attacks for the Nihilanth?
channel.description:
I think that the Nihilanth encounter in the original HL is a bit too simple. Ok, the Nih can teleport you and can launch electrical bolts, but it's too simple anyway!
The Alien Controller ([url]https://half-life.wikia.com/wiki/Alien_Controller[/url]) has a kind of attack the Nih has not: sometimes, the controller opens his head a shoot an orb to you. Why don't you give the nih a similar attack? In the moment that you crack its head open, it will make an orb that does something (AoE attack? electrical charge? destroy/disable your equipped weapon? shoots randomly in your direction? anything!)
That makes the encounter a little more complicated in the moment it needs something to maintain the climax. What do you think?

When Nihilanth is now dying, a portal storm effect will start (like in portal but mixed with the resonance cascade beams) then the gman stops time (like HL2) then teleports with you to the Endgame Stage.

item.title: Some new attacks for the Nihilanth?
item.dc:creator: lunertexcosmo
item.description:
Dr. Maxwell:

I think that the nature of the Nihilanth’s teleportation attack definitely needs revision. In the original game, the amount of time and effort it always took to get back from the teleported locations caused me to treat them as insta-kills, and whenever I was hit by a teleport sphere, I always hit the quick-load key. Either the locations the Nihilanth teleports you to need to be somewhere necessary for progression of the battle, the teleport spheres need to be non-dodge-able and inevitable, or the teleport attack needs to be replaced with something else.

This. Those were more irritating than the orbs he throws at you. By inevitable and non-dodge-able, I presume you mean the teleports are scripted and occur only when they’re supposed to? I’d like that.

And I think the Garg and Ichy need to go. It’s really unnecessary and irritating to have to fight around other bosses while fighting another boss. Same goes for the other aliens in the fight. When I’m in boss mode, I don’t need a bunch of Vorts and Controllers hovering around me.

My tactic:

  1. Immediately camp behind big rock
  2. Take out crystals with 2 crossbow shots each
  3. Make sure that green orbs hit the rock, or I can take them down with crossbow (yes, you can do that)

  7. Watch out for his remaining minions while he’s dying

It was just too simple, so you should make it harder.

Yeah, I always thought that Nihilant was pretty easy, but I guess they already know that, probably that’s changed already

item.title: Some new attacks for the Nihilanth?
item.dc:creator: Pettifogg
item.description:
BahamutBBob:

I thought I saw a Mark Laidlaw quote saying somethign along the lines of Nihilanth didn’t care about Earth, it was just one step further from the Combine. When the resonance cascade happened, he saw an opportunity and took it.

No ill will towards humanity, but no compassion, either. He’s just doing what it takes to survive and flee the Combine.

I think these are the quotes you mean:

Marc Laidlaw:

We had a glimpse of the larger threat when we were working on Half Life 1. In other words we knew that once you cleared out the nihilanth, you were going to discover something worse beyond it. We knew that some immense threat had chased the Nihilanth and its creatures out of their own world and into Xen, from which location they were all to glad to seize the opportunity to continue on to earth with suppression through the citadels. But the exact nature of the threat was left to be solved in Half Life 2.

Marc Laidlaw:

Yes, that’s fairly accurate, and I’m pretty sure Doug was restating something I’d told him; I am not clarifying it, since it’s the foundation on which the series continues. What we saw in HL 1 was the very end of a long struggle between the Combine and the last of the Nihilanth’s race…although it’s a bit different than the word “prompted” implies. The Nihilanth’s “world” (if it could be said to have) was long since in the past as far as the Nihilanth was concerned; Xen was their final retreat, and they had their back to the wall, as it were, when the fissure appeared that let them spill into our dimension. Xen itself is sort of a dimensional transit bottleneck–an area of continual contention.

item.title: Some new attacks for the Nihilanth?
item.dc:creator: Eion_Kilant_739
item.description:
TCMOREIRA:

I dunno if anyone said something like that before but…

Well in my point of view, Nihillant doesn’t want to fight with gordon because altough he is powerfull he’s not strong enough to fight with gordon.He knows the consequences of losing this fight, Gordon doesn’t. The reason why Nihillant keeps teleporting Gordon is because he does not want this fight to happen. Nihilant is the only thing between G-Man,the Combine and the future damnation of everything.
I just really want you guys to keep what Nihillant says to gordon when he dies, that’s some important stuff…
Also the fight must be something like “Im not your enemy you pathetic fool”…

EDIT: Just checked your posting history. So sorry, I’ve gotten you mixed up with the waves and waves of other new people and overracted. The mis-directed parts of the original post is viewable if you highlight/select it.

[COLOR=‘Black’]Sir and or Ma’am. I want you to take a step back here. I know you are very eager about the mod, we all are, but you can’t step blindingly into stuff.

I used to be like you and I made some similarly bad and silly posts when I first came here. Your problem is that what you are suggesting (aside from any spelling and grammar mistakes it may have) is unreasonable. What you said does not fit or add up.

A word of advice: Don’t post if someone has said exactly what you have said unless you have something to add. I would also heavily reccomend that you have played through Half-Life and Half-Life 2 or atleast have watched a play-through of it.

Of course this isn’t directed only at this post of yours but some of your previous posts of yours aswell (unless I am confusing you with the other slew of new members).

I do understand your general idea though. You want the Ninilanth to show more signs of the consequences faced if he is killed. Unfortunately this is untrue. The Ninilanth is a slave-worker, effectively, and the Combine only become aware of something to conquer because of how “noisy” the space-stuff incident in Black Mesa was.
